Good game, very good game

So far, I like it, I thought it was going to be the exact same thing as Conter Strikejust in a WWII setting but it was fairly different, in fact I like it more than Counter Strike, I just wish it had and offline mode because I have the worst internet possible and internet lag kills.

For a $5, 2004 game, this has to be some of the most genuine fun I have ever had in a FPS. Once you have looked past the graphics you get a great game with so much structure. Choose either the Axis or the Allies and from there you have a wide range of classes for different weapon types. This game is so well structured because of its community. If someone sees someone in an assult class then they will go long ranged to co-operate with the assult class instead of your average, load-out based FPS where people choose weapons because they like them. I highly reccomended Day of Defeat for these reasons and if you are still tossing and turning, wait until it is on sale when it goes down to $2.50.

A World War II FPS, A Half-Life mod, the weapon mechanics flow at times better than FPS of todays games (Call of Duty and Battlefield). With zooming only when you have a weapon with a scope. Modellic graphics are expected. I would still play this today. There are several different servers still up as well as dedicated players. Hacking is pretty nonexistant, although its always best to be in the right servers (this happens to many games).
Despite the basic graphics, Day of Defeat is a fun game.

Day of Defeat is an extremely fun and addicting multiplayer shooter. Many people may tell you that the game sucks, but that's probably because they're addicted to spray-and-pray games like Call of Duty. In Day of Defeat, it requires more strategy, and is by far more realistic. Anybody who enjoys studying WWII and playing games will find this a nice treat. Play and would recommend everyone to try who have not yet felt on his entire "beauty" of this game!

Bom jogo de guerra
Classics never die.

Day of Defeat was my ultimate competitive multiplayer experience in my early teens. It's a class-based WWII shooter where different classes have different weapon loadouts. Unlike modern FPS games, guns have a kickback YOU have to actively compensate for, and grenades (your own and your enemy's) can be picked up and thrown after the pin has been pulled, making grenades much more versitile and strategic, something that even Day of Defeat: Source lost by replacing traditional grenades with grenade launchers. You can also legitimately focus on stealth and melee.

Day Of Defeat is another of the free modifications for Half-Life that, with the help of Valve, got turned into a full fledged retail release. Often overshadowed by it's significantly more popular older brother, Counter-Strike, Day Of Defeat is a relatively unknown to many and while it doesn't quite live up to the standards set by similar retail games it does provide a decent World War II experience.

Day Of Defeat pits the German Army against either the British or American forces, which one is chosen depends on the map being played, in relatively small surroundings. Although it is not a game that aims for any sort of uber realism it does feature a number of mechanics to encourage slower and more realistic behavior such as a stamina bar and significantly decreased accuracy when moving. Respawning into the battle happens in waves which keeps the action going and prevents too much downtime but unfortunately also encourages less entertaining behavior such as spawn camping.

The class based system is fairly limited and only changes the weapons you use which creates a rather bland experience.

Graphically it is clear that the old Half-Life engine has run it's course, Day Of Defeat is by no means a good looking game and the lack of detail can get distracting at times especially when considering that it's main rival is the stellar looking Battlefield 1942.

All in all Day Of Defeat is a mod success. The people that played it before it turned retail are the people that's going to play it afterwards, it's not a game that's looking to pick up any new fans in the transition. Perhaps it is easier to understand if you view this, not as a game going from mod to retail. But as a team of developers going from amateurs to professionals. It is an astonishing accomplishment and I wish them all the best in their future endeavors, I am just not really sure I want to pay for their advancement.

There is still many players out there. A lot of ole timers and quite a few new players. Of course the game has died down some.... just a bit since it came out. You know times change and so does the playing fields. However, I still see quite a few players throughout the week that are committed to playing this classic "Broken Valve Mod", But we still love it. There are hundreds of maps that the community was able to build and supply players to keep the games alive. I still see maps I never heard of being played on servers. I mean honestly, I see more maps for these old games than any of the new ones I play..... Plus I do not have to buy the maps. You just go to a server and download the map, then play time, game on. User Contributed Files RULE!
This game is the shit! BUY IT

With Half-Life's release, World War II shooters were not common. You had Wolfenstein 3D, and some others. This was a good precursor to all World War II shooters. I'd recommend picking this up to see what it was life back then.

I highly recomend buying this game, you will have tons of fun. Plus its only $5!

If you have an extra $5 (or even $2.50, depending on the Steam sale) buy this shit. So fun... brings back so many memories of the oldschool gaming days... Like many other games in the Valve franchise, ahead of its time

Un Counter  Strike en 39-45? No prob! Voici Day of Defeat! Même si les graphismes peuvent parraître d'une autre époque (Half-Life/Counter-Strike), le jeu ne perd absolument pas de son charme. Choisissez votre équipe: Alliés (Américains ou Anglais certaines fois et selon les serveurs) ou Axe ( les méchants Allemands, mais c'est un jeu, ne l'oublions pas !), choisissez votre arme (Springfield/ Sharchfefeazf... fusil à lunette allemand quoi!, Thompson/Unteroffizer, Bar/Sturmstrup, M1Garand/K98 (Grenadier), Bazzoka/Panzerschrek, Mitrailleuse Lourde/MG42 ou 34... (l'orthographe allemande est ici incertaine)) et partez sur le champ de bataille conquérir chaque points de contrôle (drapeaux) et ainsi faire gagner son équipe.
À oui aussi, c'est un FPS en multi à la façon de Counter Strike.
Très bon jeu de tir, intuitif et défouloir.

So this is the older version of Day of Defeats... Not sure what to say. It's fun? Might as well get source though.
